seisflows3.tools.msg

SeisFlows3 messages tool. For providing a uniform look to SeisFlows3 print and log statements that end up in stdout or in log files.

Module Contents

seisflows3.tools.msg.DEG = °
seisflows3.tools.msg.mjr(val, char='=')

Message formatter used to block off sections in log files with visually distinctive separators. Defined as individual functions to reduce call length.

Major: For important or workflow.main() messages like starting workflow

>>> print(msg.mjr(“Important message here”)) or >>> logger.info.(msg.mjr(“Important message here”))

Parameters

  • val (str) – formatted message to return

  • char (str) – border character to separate the message from remainder of logs

Return type

str

Returns

formatted string message to be printed to std out

seisflows3.tools.msg.mnr(val, char='/')

Message formatter used to block off sections in log files with visually distinctive separators. Defined as individual functions to reduce call length.

Minor: For key messages, describing things like what iteration were at

>>> print(msg.mnr(“Semi important message here”)) OR >>> logger.info.(msg.mnr(“Semi important message here”))

Parameters

  • val (str) – formatted message to return

  • char (str) – border character to separate the message from remainder of logs

Return type

str

Returns

formatted string message to be printed to std out

seisflows3.tools.msg.sub(val, char='-')

Message formatter used to block off sections in log files with visually distinctive separators. Defined as individual functions to reduce call length.

Sub: For sub-critical messages, describing things like notes and warnings

>>> print(msg.mnr(“Sub-critical message here”)) OR >>> logger.info.(msg.sub(“Sub-critical message here”))

Parameters

  • val (str) – formatted message to return

  • char (str) – border character to separate the message from remainder of logs

Return type

str

Returns

formatted string message to be printed to std out

seisflows3.tools.msg.cli(text='', items=None, wraplen=80, header=None, border=None, hchar='/')

Provide a standardized look to the SeisFlows command line interface messages The look we are after is something like:

$ seisflows cmd

text item1 item2 … itemN =======================

$ ls -l

Parameters

  • text (str) – text to format into the cli look

  • items (list) – optional list of items that will be displayed on new lines after the text. Useful for listing parameters or paths. The items here are NOT wrapped.

  • wraplen (int) – desired line length to wrap messages.

  • header (str) – optional header line that will be centered (wraplen/2) and capitalized. Useful for things like ‘WARNING’ and ‘ERROR’

  • border (str) – a character to use to block off

  • hchar (str) – character to underline the header with

Rtype output_str

str

Return output_str

formatted string to print out

seisflows3.tools.msg.write_par_file_header(f, paths_or_parameters, name='', tabsize=4, border='=', uline='/')

Re-usable function to write docstring comments inside the SeisFlows3 parameter file. Used by seisflows.SeisFlows.configure()

Headers look something like this

# =========================== # MODULE NAME # /////////// # PAR (type): # description of par # =========================== PAR: val

Parameters

  • f (_io.TextIO) – open text file to write to

  • paths_or_parameters (dict) – the paths or parameters that should be written to the header

  • name (str) – the name of the module that is being written, will be used as the header of the docstring

  • tabsize (int) – how large to expand tab character ‘ ‘ as spaces

  • border (str) – character to use as the header and footer border

  • uline (str) – how to underline the header

seisflows3.tools.msg.write_par_file_paths_pars(f, paths_or_parameters, indent=0, tabsize=4)

Re-usable function to write paths or parameters in yaml format to the SeisFlows3 parameter file. Used by seisflows.SeisFlows.configure()

Parameters are written something like:

PAR1: val1 PAR2: val2 Par3:

  • val3a

  • val3b

  • val3c

Parameters

  • f (_io.TextIO) – open text file to write to

  • paths_or_parameters (dict) – the paths or parameters that should be written to the header

  • indent (int) – level of indentation to match yaml style. passed to str.expandtabs(tabsize=`indent`)

  • tabsize (int) – how large to expand tab character ‘ ‘ as spaces
